sn22.84:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā tisso bhagavato pitucchāputto sambahulānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ evamāroceti:
sn22.84:1.2.eng: Now at that time Venerable Tissa—the Buddha’s cousin on his father’s side—informed several mendicants:
sn22.84:1.2.comm: Tissa’s further struggles are at SN 21.9.

sn22.84:1.3.pli: “api me, āvuso, madhurakajāto viya kāyo; disāpi me na pakkhāyanti; dhammāpi maṃ na paṭibhanti; thinamiddhañca me cittaṃ pariyādāya tiṭṭhati; anabhirato ca brahmacariyaṃ carāmi; hoti ca me dhammesu vicikicchā”ti.
sn22.84:1.3.eng: “Reverends, my body feels like it’s drugged. I’m disorientated, the teachings don’t spring to mind, and dullness and drowsiness fill my mind. I lead the spiritual life dissatisfied, and have doubts about the teachings.”

sn22.84:2.1.pli: Atha kho sambahulā bhikkhū yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho te bhikkhū bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ:
sn22.84:2.1.eng: Then several mendicants went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened.

sn22.84:2.2.pli: “āyasmā, bhante, tisso bhagavato pitucchāputto sambahulānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ evamāroceti:

sn22.84:2.3.pli: ‘api me, āvuso, madhurakajāto viya kāyo; disāpi me na pakkhāyanti; dhammāpi maṃ na paṭibhanti; thinamiddhañca me cittaṃ pariyādāya tiṭṭhati; anabhirato ca brahmacariyaṃ carāmi; hoti ca me dhammesu vicikicchā’”ti.

sn22.84:3.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā aññataraṃ bhikkhuṃ āmantesi:
sn22.84:3.1.eng: So the Buddha addressed one of the monks,

sn22.84:3.2.pli: “ehi tvaṃ, bhikkhu, mama vacanena tissaṃ bhikkhuṃ āmantehī”ti.
sn22.84:3.2.eng: “Please, monk, in my name tell the mendicant Tissa that the Teacher summons him.”
sn22.84:3.2.comm: The expected phrase “the Teacher summons him” is absent in Mahāsaṅgīti, but present in PTS.

sn22.84:3.3.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho so bhikkhu bhagavato paṭissutvā yenāyasmā tisso tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ tissaṃ etadavoca:
sn22.84:3.3.eng: “Yes, sir,” that monk replied. He went to Tissa and said to him,

sn22.84:3.5.pli: “Evamāvuso”ti kho āyasmā tisso tassa bhikkhuno paṭissutvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho āyasmantaṃ tissaṃ bhagavā etadavoca:
sn22.84:3.5.eng: “Yes, reverend,” Tissa replied. He went to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to him:

sn22.84:3.6.pli: “saccaṃ kira tvaṃ, tissa, sambahulānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ evamārocesi:
sn22.84:3.6.eng: “Is it really true, Tissa, that you informed several mendicants that

sn22.84:3.7.pli: ‘api me, āvuso, madhurakajāto viya kāyo …pe… hoti ca me dhammesu vicikicchā’”ti?
sn22.84:3.7.eng: your body feels like it’s drugged … and you have doubts about the teachings?”

sn22.84:3.10.pli: rūpe avigatarāgassa avigatacchandassa avigatapemassa avigatapipāsassa avigatapariḷāhassa avigatataṇhassa, tassa rūpassa vipariṇāmaññathābhāvā uppajjanti sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā”ti?
sn22.84:3.10.eng: If you’re not rid of greed, desire, fondness, thirst, passion, and craving for form, when that form decays and perishes, will it give rise to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress?”

sn22.84:4.1.comm: The Buddha’s incredible skill in teaching. His encouragement is not mere platitudes; he first draws out Tissa’s actual wisdom, then he praises that.

sn22.84:4.3.eng: when you’re not rid of greed for form.

sn22.84:4.4.eng: If you’re not rid of greed for feeling …

sn22.84:5.3.pli: Yathā taṃ saṅkhāresu anigatarāgassa, viññāṇe avigatarāgassa avigatacchandassa avigatapemassa avigatapipāsassa avigatapariḷāhassa avigatataṇhassa, tassa viññāṇassa vipariṇāmaññathābhāvā uppajjanti sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā”ti?
sn22.84:5.3.eng: consciousness, when that consciousness decays and perishes, will it give rise to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress?”

sn22.84:6.3.eng: when you’re not rid of greed for consciousness.

sn22.84:6.5.pli: rūpe vigatarāgassa vigatacchandassa vigatapemassa vigatapipāsassa vigatapariḷāhassa vigatataṇhassa, tassa rūpassa vipariṇāmaññathābhāvā uppajjanti sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā”ti?
sn22.84:6.5.eng: If you are rid of greed, desire, fondness, thirst, passion, and craving for form, when that form decays and perishes, will it give rise to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress?”

sn22.84:7.3.eng: when you are rid of greed for form …

sn22.84:7.7.pli: viññāṇe vigatarāgassa vigatacchandassa vigatapemassa vigatapipāsassa vigatapariḷāhassa vigatataṇhassa tassa viññāṇassa vipariṇāmaññathābhāvā uppajjanti sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā”ti?

sn22.84:8.14.eng: They understand: ‘… there is nothing further for this place.’

sn22.84:9.1.eng: Suppose, Tissa, there were two individuals.

sn22.84:9.2.pli: eko puriso amaggakusalo, eko puriso maggakusalo.
sn22.84:9.2.eng: One was not skilled in the path, the other was.

sn22.84:9.3.pli: Tamenaṃ so amaggakusalo puriso amuṃ maggakusalaṃ purisaṃ maggaṃ puccheyya.
sn22.84:9.3.eng: The one not skilled in the path would question the one skilled in the path,

sn22.84:9.5.eng: ‘Come, good man, this is the path.

sn22.84:9.7.pli: Tena muhuttaṃ gantvā dakkhissasi dvedhāpathaṃ, tattha vāmaṃ muñcitvā dakkhiṇaṃ gaṇhāhi.
sn22.84:9.7.eng: and you’ll see a fork in the road. Ignore the left, and take the right-hand path.

sn22.84:9.9.pli: Tena muhuttaṃ gantvā dakkhissasi tibbaṃ vanasaṇḍaṃ.
sn22.84:9.9.eng: and you’ll see a dense forest grove.

sn22.84:9.11.pli: Tena muhuttaṃ gantvā dakkhissasi mahantaṃ ninnaṃ pallalaṃ.
sn22.84:9.11.eng: and you’ll see an expanse of low-lying marshes.

sn22.84:9.13.pli: Tena muhuttaṃ gantvā dakkhissasi sobbhaṃ papātaṃ.
sn22.84:9.13.eng: and you’ll see a large, steep cliff.

sn22.84:9.15.pli: Tena muhuttaṃ gantvā dakkhissasi samaṃ bhūmibhāgaṃ ramaṇīyan’ti.
sn22.84:9.15.eng: and you’ll see level, cleared parkland.’

sn22.84:10.1.pli: Upamā kho myāyaṃ, tissa, katā atthassa viññāpanāya.
sn22.84:10.1.eng: I’ve made up this simile to make a point.

sn22.84:10.2.eng: And this is what it means.

sn22.84:10.3.eng: ‘A person who is not skilled in the path’ is a term for an ordinary unlearned person.

sn22.84:10.4.pli: ‘Puriso maggakusalo’ti kho, tissa, tathāgatassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ arahato sammāsambuddhassa.
sn22.84:10.4.eng: ‘A person who is skilled in the path’ is a term for the Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.

sn22.84:10.5.eng: ‘A fork in the road’ is a term for doubt.

sn22.84:10.6.pli: ‘Vāmo maggo’ti kho, tissa, aṭṭhaṅgikassetaṃ micchāmaggassa adhivacanaṃ, seyyathidaṃ—
sn22.84:10.6.eng: ‘The left-hand path’ is a term for the wrong eightfold path, that is,

sn22.84:10.8.pli: ‘Dakkhiṇo maggo’ti kho, tissa, ariyassetaṃ aṭṭhaṅgikassa maggassa adhivacanaṃ, seyyathidaṃ—
sn22.84:10.8.eng: ‘The right-hand path’ is a term for the noble eightfold path, that is,

sn22.84:10.10.eng: ‘A dense forest grove’ is a term for ignorance.

sn22.84:10.11.pli: ‘Mahantaṃ ninnaṃ pallalan’ti kho, tissa, kāmānametaṃ adhivacanaṃ.
sn22.84:10.11.eng: ‘An expanse of low-lying marshes’ is a term for sensual pleasures.

sn22.84:10.12.eng: ‘A large, steep cliff’ is a term for anger and distress.

sn22.84:10.13.pli: ‘Samo bhūmibhāgo ramaṇīyo’ti kho, tissa, nibbānassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ.
sn22.84:10.13.eng: ‘Level, cleared parkland’ is a term for extinguishment.

sn22.84:10.15.eng: I am here with advice, with support, with instruction.”
sn22.84:10.15.comm: This sentence lacks a verb, so we assume homi, “I am”.

sn22.84:11.1.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

sn22.84:11.2.pli: Attamano āyasmā tisso bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandīti.
sn22.84:11.2.eng: Satisfied, Venerable Tissa approved what the Buddha said.

sn22.85:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ āyasmā sāriputto sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
sn22.85:1.1.eng: At one time Venerable Sāriputta was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

sn22.85:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena yamakassa nāma bhikkhuno evarūpaṃ pāpakaṃ diṭṭhigataṃ uppannaṃ hoti:
sn22.85:1.2.eng: Now at that time a mendicant called Yamaka had the following harmful misconception:

sn22.85:1.3.pli: “tathāhaṃ bhagavatā dhammaṃ desitaṃ ājānāmi, yathā khīṇāsavo bhikkhu kāyassa bhedā ucchijjati vinassati, na hoti paraṃ maraṇā”ti.
sn22.85:1.3.eng: “As I understand the Buddha’s teaching, a mendicant who has ended the defilements is annihilated and destroyed when their body breaks up, and doesn’t exist after death.”
sn22.85:1.3.comm: He equates the Buddha’s teaching of cessation with annihilation. Not all annihilationists believe that there is only one lifetime. Some, for example, believed that there is an allotted course of lives, perhaps predetermined, at the end of which all beings come to an end, as “transmigration is limited” (pariyantakate saṁsāre, DN 2:20.9, SN 24.8:1.13). Such was the doctrine taught by the Bamboo-staffed Ascetic Gosāla to the Ājīvakas.

sn22.85:2.1.pli: Assosuṃ kho sambahulā bhikkhū yamakassa kira nāma bhikkhuno evarūpaṃ pāpakaṃ diṭṭhigataṃ uppannaṃ hoti:

sn22.85:2.2.pli: “tathāhaṃ bhagavatā dhammaṃ desitaṃ ājānāmi, yathā khīṇāsavo bhikkhu kāyassa bhedā ucchijjati vinassati, na hoti paraṃ maraṇā”ti.

sn22.85:2.3.pli: Atha kho te bhikkhū yenāyasmā yamako tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmatā yamakena saddhiṃ sammodiṃsu.
sn22.85:2.3.eng: They went to Yamaka and exchanged greetings with him.

sn22.85:2.4.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho te bhikkhū āyasmantaṃ yamakaṃ etadavocuṃ:
sn22.85:2.4.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, they sat down to one side and said to him,

sn22.85:3.1.pli: “Saccaṃ kira te, āvuso yamaka, evarūpaṃ pāpakaṃ diṭṭhigataṃ uppannaṃ:
sn22.85:3.1.eng: “Is it really true, Reverend Yamaka, that you have such a harmful misconception:

sn22.85:3.2.pli: ‘tathāhaṃ bhagavatā dhammaṃ desitaṃ ājānāmi, yathā khīṇāsavo bhikkhu kāyassa bhedā ucchijjati vinassati, na hoti paraṃ maraṇā’”ti?
sn22.85:3.2.eng: ‘As I understand the Buddha’s teaching, a mendicant who has ended the defilements is annihilated and destroyed when their body breaks up, and doesn’t exist after death’?”

sn22.85:3.3.pli: “Evaṃ khvāhaṃ, āvuso, bhagavatā dhammaṃ desitaṃ ājānāmi:
sn22.85:3.3.eng: “Yes, reverends, that’s how I understand the Buddha’s teaching.”

sn22.85:3.4.pli: ‘khīṇāsavo bhikkhu kāyassa bhedā ucchijjati vinassati, na hoti paraṃ maraṇā’”ti.

sn22.85:4.1.pli: “Mā, āvuso yamaka, evaṃ avaca, mā bhagavantaṃ abbhācikkhi. Na hi sādhu bhagavato abbhācikkhanaṃ. Na hi bhagavā evaṃ vadeyya:
sn22.85:4.1.eng: “Don’t say that, Yamaka! Don’t misrepresent the Buddha, for misrepresentation of the Buddha is not good. And the Buddha would not say that.”

sn22.85:4.2.pli: ‘khīṇāsavo bhikkhu kāyassa bhedā ucchijjati vinassati, na hoti paraṃ maraṇā’”ti.

sn22.85:4.3.pli: Evampi kho āyasmā yamako tehi bhikkhūhi vuccamāno tatheva taṃ pāpakaṃ diṭṭhigataṃ thāmasā parāmāsā abhinivissa voharati:
sn22.85:4.3.eng: But even though admonished by those mendicants, Yamaka obstinately stuck to that misconception and insisted on stating it.

sn22.85:4.4.pli: “tathāhaṃ bhagavatā dhammaṃ desitaṃ ājānāmi, yathā khīṇāsavo bhikkhu kāyassa bhedā ucchijjati vinassati, na hoti paraṃ maraṇā”ti.

sn22.85:5.1.pli: Yato kho te bhikkhū nāsakkhiṃsu āyasmantaṃ yamakaṃ etasmā pāpakā diṭṭhigatā vivecetuṃ, atha kho te bhikkhū uṭṭhāyāsanā yenāyasmā sāriputto tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ sāriputtaṃ etadavocuṃ:
sn22.85:5.1.eng: When those mendicants were unable to dissuade Yamaka from that misconception, they got up from their seats and went to see Venerable Sāriputta. They told him what had happened, and said,

sn22.85:5.2.pli: “yamakassa nāma, āvuso sāriputta, bhikkhuno evarūpaṃ pāpakaṃ diṭṭhigataṃ uppannaṃ:

sn22.85:5.3.pli: ‘tathāhaṃ bhagavatā dhammaṃ desitaṃ ājānāmi yathā khīṇāsavo bhikkhu kāyassa bhedā ucchijjati vinassati, na hoti paraṃ maraṇā’ti.

sn22.85:5.4.pli: Sādhāyasmā sāriputto yena yamako bhikkhu tenupasaṅkamatu anukampaṃ upādāyā”ti.
sn22.85:5.4.eng: “May Venerable Sāriputta please go to the mendicant Yamaka out of sympathy.”

sn22.85:5.6.pli: Atha kho āyasmā sāriputto sāyanhasamayaṃ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito yenāyasmā yamako tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmatā yamakena saddhiṃ sammodi …pe… ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā sāriputto āyasmantaṃ yamakaṃ etadavoca:
sn22.85:5.6.eng: Then in the late afternoon, Venerable Sāriputta came out of retreat, went to Venerable Yamaka and exchanged greetings with him. Seated to one side he said to Yamaka:

sn22.85:6.1.pli: “Saccaṃ kira te, āvuso yamaka, evarūpaṃ pāpakaṃ diṭṭhigataṃ uppannaṃ:
sn22.85:6.1.eng: “Is it really true, Reverend Yamaka, that you have such a harmful misconception:

sn22.85:6.2.pli: ‘tathāhaṃ bhagavatā dhammaṃ desitaṃ ājānāmi, yathā khīṇāsavo bhikkhu kāyassa bhedā ucchijjati vinassati, na hoti paraṃ maraṇā’”ti?
sn22.85:6.2.eng: ‘As I understand the Buddha’s teaching, a mendicant who has ended the defilements is annihilated and destroyed when their body breaks up, and doesn’t exist after death’?”

sn22.85:6.3.pli: “Evaṃ khvāhaṃ, āvuso, bhagavatā dhammaṃ desitaṃ ājānāmi, yathā khīṇāsavo bhikkhu kāyassa bhedā ucchijjati vinassati, na hoti paraṃ maraṇā”ti.
sn22.85:6.3.eng: “Yes, reverend, that’s how I understand the Buddha’s teaching.”

sn22.85:7.11.eng: They understand: ‘… there is nothing further for this place.’

sn22.85:8.1.eng: What do you think, Reverend Yamaka?

sn22.85:8.2.eng: Do you regard a realized one as form?”
sn22.85:8.2.comm: “Realized one” (tathāgata) commonly refers to the Buddha himself, but it may also refer to any arahant. In this and similar passages, the nature of the arahant is discussed, and it does not directly bear on the Buddha specifically, so I take it as referring to any arahant.

sn22.85:8.4.eng: “Do you regard a realized one as feeling …

sn22.85:9.2.eng: Do you regard a realized one as in form?”

sn22.85:9.4.eng: “Or do you regard a realized one as distinct from form?”

sn22.85:9.6.eng: “Do you regard a realized one as in feeling …

sn22.85:9.14.eng: “Or do you regard a realized one as distinct from consciousness?”

sn22.85:10.2.pli: rūpaṃ … vedanaṃ … saññaṃ … saṅkhāre … viññāṇaṃ tathāgatoti samanupassasī”ti?
sn22.85:10.2.eng: Do you regard a realized one as possessing form … feeling … perception … choices … consciousness?”
sn22.85:10.2.comm: The commentary says this means lumping all the aggregates together. However, the negative passage just below uses the possessive forms, and I take it that this was intended here as well.

sn22.85:11.2.pli: ayaṃ so arūpī … avedano … asaññī … asaṅkhāro … aviññāṇo tathāgatoti samanupassasī”ti?
sn22.85:11.2.eng: Do you regard a realized one as without form … feeling … perception … choices … consciousness?”

sn22.85:11.4.pli: “Ettha ca te, āvuso yamaka, diṭṭheva dhamme saccato thetato tathāgate anupalabbhiyamāne, kallaṃ nu te taṃ veyyākaraṇaṃ:
sn22.85:11.4.eng: “In that case, Reverend Yamaka, since a realized one is not found by you as a genuine fact in this very life, is it cogent for you to declare:

sn22.85:11.5.pli: ‘tathāhaṃ bhagavatā dhammaṃ desitaṃ ājānāmi, yathā khīṇāsavo bhikkhu kāyassa bhedā ucchijjati vinassati, na hoti paraṃ maraṇā’”ti?
sn22.85:11.5.eng: ‘As I understand the Buddha’s teaching, a mendicant who has ended the defilements is annihilated and destroyed when their body breaks up, and doesn’t exist after death.’?”

sn22.85:12.1.pli: “Ahu kho me taṃ, āvuso sāriputta, pubbe aviddasuno pāpakaṃ diṭṭhigataṃ;
sn22.85:12.1.eng: “Reverend Sāriputta, in my ignorance, I used to have that misconception.

sn22.85:12.2.pli: idañca panāyasmato sāriputtassa dhammadesanaṃ sutvā tañceva pāpakaṃ diṭṭhigataṃ pahīnaṃ, dhammo ca me abhisamito”ti.
sn22.85:12.2.eng: But now that I’ve heard the teaching from Venerable Sāriputta, I’ve given up that misconception, and I’ve comprehended the teaching.”

sn22.85:13.1.eng: “Reverend Yamaka, suppose they were to ask you:

sn22.85:13.2.pli: ‘yo so, āvuso yamaka, bhikkhu arahaṃ khīṇāsavo so kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā kiṃ hotī’ti?
sn22.85:13.2.eng: ‘When their body breaks up, after death, what happens to a perfected one, who has ended the defilements?’

sn22.85:13.3.pli: Evaṃ puṭṭho tvaṃ, āvuso yamaka, kinti byākareyyāsī”ti?

sn22.85:13.4.eng: “Reverend, if they were to ask this,

sn22.85:13.5.pli: ‘yo so, āvuso yamaka, bhikkhu arahaṃ khīṇāsavo so kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā kiṃ hotī’ti?

sn22.85:13.9.eng: What’s suffering has ceased and disappeared.

sn22.85:13.15.eng: What’s suffering has ceased and disappeared.’

sn22.85:13.16.eng: That’s how I’d answer such a question.”

sn22.85:14.2.pli: Tena hāvuso yamaka, upamaṃ te karissāmi etasseva atthassa bhiyyoso mattāya ñāṇāya.
sn22.85:14.2.eng: Well then, I shall give you a simile to make the meaning even clearer.

sn22.85:14.3.pli: Seyyathāpi, āvuso yamaka, gahapati vā gahapatiputto vā aḍḍho mahaddhano mahābhogo;
sn22.85:14.3.eng: Suppose there was a householder or householder’s son who was rich, with a lot of money and great wealth,

sn22.85:14.5.pli: Tassa kocideva puriso uppajjeyya anatthakāmo ahitakāmo ayogakkhemakāmo jīvitā voropetukāmo.
sn22.85:14.5.eng: Then along comes a person who wants to harm, injure, and threaten him, and take his life.

sn22.85:14.7.pli: ‘ayaṃ kho gahapati vā gahapatiputto vā aḍḍho mahaddhano mahābhogo;
sn22.85:14.7.eng: ‘This householder or householder’s son is rich, with a lot of money and great wealth,

sn22.85:14.9.eng: It won’t be easy to take his life by force.

sn22.85:14.10.eng: Why don’t I get close to him, then take his life?’

sn22.85:14.11.pli: So taṃ gahapatiṃ vā gahapatiputtaṃ vā upasaṅkamitvā evaṃ vadeyya:
sn22.85:14.11.eng: So he goes up to that householder or householder’s son and says:

sn22.85:14.13.pli: Tamenaṃ so gahapati vā gahapatiputto vā upaṭṭhāpeyya.
sn22.85:14.13.eng: They would serve that householder or householder’s son.

sn22.85:14.14.pli: So upaṭṭhaheyya pubbuṭṭhāyī pacchānipātī kiṅkārapaṭissāvī manāpacārī piyavādī.
sn22.85:14.14.eng: They’d get up before him and go to bed after him, and be obliging, behaving nicely and speaking politely.

sn22.85:14.15.pli: Tassa so gahapati vā gahapatiputto vā mittatopi naṃ saddaheyya;
sn22.85:14.15.eng: The householder or householder’s son would consider them as a friend

sn22.85:14.18.pli: Yadā kho, āvuso, tassa purisassa evamassa:
sn22.85:14.18.eng: But when that person realizes that

sn22.85:14.19.pli: ‘saṃvissattho kho myāyaṃ gahapati vā gahapatiputto vā’ti, atha naṃ rahogataṃ viditvā tiṇhena satthena jīvitā voropeyya.
sn22.85:14.19.eng: they’ve gained the trust of the householder or householder’s son, then, when they know he’s alone, they’d take his life with a sharp knife.

sn22.85:15.2.pli: yadā hi so puriso amuṃ gahapatiṃ vā gahapatiputtaṃ vā upasaṅkamitvā evaṃ āha:
sn22.85:15.2.eng: When that person went to the householder or householder’s son and offered to

sn22.85:15.3.eng: serve him, weren’t they a killer then,

sn22.85:15.6.pli: Yadāpi so upaṭṭhahati pubbuṭṭhāyī pacchānipātī kiṅkārapaṭissāvī manāpacārī piyavādī, tadāpi so vadhakova.
sn22.85:15.6.eng: And when they got up before him and went to bed after him, being obliging, behaving nicely and speaking politely, weren’t they a killer then,

sn22.85:15.9.pli: Yadāpi naṃ rahogataṃ viditvā tiṇhena satthena jīvitā voropeti, tadāpi so vadhakova.
sn22.85:15.9.eng: And when, knowing he was alone, they took his life with a sharp knife, weren’t they a killer then,

sn22.85:15.13.pli: “Evameva kho, āvuso, assutavā puthujjano ariyānaṃ adassāvī ariyadhammassa akovido ariyadhamme avinīto, sappurisānaṃ adassāvī sappurisadhammassa akovido sappurisadhamme avinīto
sn22.85:15.13.eng: “In the same way, an unlearned ordinary person has not seen the noble ones, and is neither skilled nor trained in the teaching of the noble ones. They’ve not seen true persons, and are neither skilled nor trained in the teaching of the true persons.

sn22.85:15.14.pli: rūpaṃ attato samanupassati, rūpavantaṃ vā attānaṃ; attani vā rūpaṃ, rūpasmiṃ vā attānaṃ.
sn22.85:15.14.eng: They regard form as self, self as having form, form in self, or self in form.

sn22.85:15.18.pli: viññāṇaṃ attato samanupassati, viññāṇavantaṃ vā attānaṃ; attani vā viññāṇaṃ, viññāṇasmiṃ vā attānaṃ.
sn22.85:15.18.eng: They regard consciousness as self, self as having consciousness, consciousness in self, or self in consciousness.

sn22.85:16.1.pli: So aniccaṃ rūpaṃ ‘aniccaṃ rūpan’ti yathābhūtaṃ nappajānāti.
sn22.85:16.1.eng: They don’t truly understand form—which is impermanent—as impermanent.

sn22.85:17.1.eng: They don’t truly understand form—which is suffering—as suffering.

sn22.85:18.1.eng: They don’t truly understand form—which is not-self—as not-self.

sn22.85:19.1.eng: They don’t truly understand form—which is conditioned—as conditioned.

sn22.85:20.1.eng: They don’t truly understand form—which is a killer—as a killer.

sn22.85:20.5.eng: consciousness—which is a killer—as a killer.

sn22.85:21.1.pli: So rūpaṃ upeti upādiyati adhiṭṭhāti ‘attā me’ti.
sn22.85:21.1.eng: They’re attracted to form, grasp it, and fixate on the thought, ‘my self’.
sn22.85:21.1.comm: This phrase is also at SN 12.15:2.5 = SN 22.90:9.6.

sn22.85:21.5.eng: consciousness, grasp it, and fixate on the thought, ‘my self’.

sn22.85:21.6.pli: Tassime pañcupādānakkhandhā upetā upādinnā dīgharattaṃ ahitāya dukkhāya saṃvattanti.
sn22.85:21.6.eng: And when you’ve gotten involved with and grasped these five grasping aggregates, they lead to your lasting harm and suffering.

sn22.85:22.1.pli: Sutavā ca kho, āvuso, ariyasāvako ariyānaṃ dassāvī …pe… sappurisadhamme suvinīto
sn22.85:22.1.eng: A learned noble disciple has seen the noble ones, and is skilled and trained in the teaching of the noble ones. They’ve seen true persons, and are skilled and trained in the teaching of the true persons.

sn22.85:22.2.pli: na rūpaṃ attato samanupassati, na rūpavantaṃ attānaṃ; na attani rūpaṃ, na rūpasmiṃ attānaṃ.
sn22.85:22.2.eng: They don’t regard form as self, self as having form, form in self, or self in form.

sn22.85:22.6.pli: na viññāṇaṃ attato samanupassati, na viññāṇavantaṃ attānaṃ;
sn22.85:22.6.eng: consciousness as self, self as having consciousness,

sn22.85:22.7.pli: na attani viññāṇaṃ, na viññāṇasmiṃ attānaṃ.
sn22.85:22.7.eng: consciousness in self, or self in consciousness.

sn22.85:23.1.pli: So aniccaṃ rūpaṃ ‘aniccaṃ rūpan’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti.
sn22.85:23.1.eng: They truly understand form—which is impermanent—as impermanent.

sn22.85:24.1.eng: They truly understand form—which is suffering—as suffering.

sn22.85:25.1.eng: They truly understand form—which is not-self—as not-self.

sn22.85:26.1.eng: They truly understand form—which is conditioned—as conditioned.

sn22.85:27.1.eng: They truly understand form—which is a killer—as a killer.

sn22.85:27.5.eng: consciousness—which is a killer—as a killer.

sn22.85:28.1.pli: So rūpaṃ na upeti, na upādiyati, nādhiṭṭhāti: ‘attā me’ti.
sn22.85:28.1.eng: Not being attracted to form, they don’t grasp it, and fixate on the thought, ‘my self’.

sn22.85:28.5.pli: viññāṇaṃ na upeti, na upādiyati, nādhiṭṭhāti: ‘attā me’ti.
sn22.85:28.5.eng: consciousness, they don't grasp it, and fixate on the thought, ‘my self’.

sn22.85:28.6.pli: Tassime pañcupādānakkhandhā anupetā anupādinnā dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāya saṃvattantī”ti.
sn22.85:28.6.eng: And when you’re not attracted to and don’t grasp these five grasping aggregates, they lead to your lasting welfare and happiness.”

sn22.85:28.7.pli: “Evametaṃ, āvuso sāriputta, hoti yesaṃ āyasmantānaṃ tādisā sabrahmacārino anukampakā atthakāmā ovādakā anusāsakā.
sn22.85:28.7.eng: “Reverend Sāriputta, this is how it is when you have such venerables as spiritual companions to advise and instruct you out of kindness and sympathy.

sn22.85:28.8.pli: Idañca pana me āyasmato sāriputtassa dhammadesanaṃ sutvā anupādāya āsavehi cittaṃ vimuttan”ti.
sn22.85:28.8.eng: And after hearing this teaching by Venerable Sāriputta, my mind is freed from the defilements by not grasping.”
sn22.85:28.8.comm: Some editions add an extra sentence indicating that Yamaka rejoiced in Sāriputta’s teaching.
